Award.AwardTitle: Workshop to Broaden Participation and Increase the Competitiveness of Minority-serving Institutions in the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network will conduct a proposal development workshop for Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) aimed at increasing their awareness of opportunities and grantsmanship skills related to the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. The workshop will include two-person faculty teams from 20 MSIs interested in developing a competitive Noyce proposal. Participants will also engage in a series of post-workshop individualized sessions that will provide additional proposal guidance.

The QEM workshop and post-workshop interactions will provide participants feedback on their required project summaries to assist them in developing their ideas into competitive Noyce proposals. MSIs are uniquely qualified to address the issue of recruiting, retaining, and developing STEM teachers for high-need schools. As such, the project's workshops will help develop stronger MSIs, in general, and teacher preparation programs, specifically, to meet the nation's needs for a more productive science and technology workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In June 2017, with NSF support, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network conducted a workshop to provide technical assistance to minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to increase their participation and competitiveness in NSF's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. The two-day workshop assisted two-person teams, from MSIs with accredited teacher education programs,in further developing their ideas for Noyce proposals for the FY2018 competition. Fifty-three (53) STEM and education faculty, representing teams from twenty-two (22) MSIs in thirteen (13) states and the District of Columbia, attended the workshop (two institutions had two teams while five institutions were represented by three-person teams).

Workshop sessions included presentations by NSF Program Directors and QEM consultants. Key topics discussed at the workshops included: overview of NSF and the Noyce program tracks; NSF?s merit review process and preparation of competitive proposals;project design, data management, assessment and evaluation plans; and project sustainability and institutional change. At the end of the workshop, participants received evaluation questionnaires to solicit their feedback regarding their overall workshop experience. Forty-four of the 53 workshop participants responded to the questionnaire (83% response rate). One hundred percent (100 %) of them indicated that the workshop organization, clarity of goals, and overall experience was ?excellent?

Following the 6-month Noyce proposal review period, QEM staff search of NSF/Noyce awards database revealed that two institutional teams at the June 2017 workshop received awards in FY 2018 totaling over $1.9M.

The QEM Noyce project provided MSI faculty with hands-on training in the preparation and submission of competitive proposals to the NSF Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program as well as professional development focused on current teacher education research and best practices. Following the workshop, teams were provided with additional guidance through QEM consultant-led post workshop technical assistance activities. Overall, the project activities increased participants? proposal development skills and awareness of Noyce teacher training tracks/opportunities. 

Following the workshop, the agenda and links to presentations were posted on QEM?s website to augment notes taken by participants at the workshop and facilitate sharing with a broader audience. Participants were strongly encouraged to share information and materials from the workshop with colleagues at their institutions. Data collected through follow-up surveys showed that teams shared workshop materials with colleagues using the following avenues: 67 % shared workshop packets; 44% shared links to presentations on QEM website; and 33% shared the E-resources file. 

ABOUT QEM NETWORK

The Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network was established in 1990 as a non-profit organization in Washington, DC, dedicated to improving education for minorities throughout the nation. QEM works with minority and non-minority individuals, organizations, and institutions to help coordinate and energize efforts to improve the education of minorities, particularly in STEM.
